Description: Federal/provincial works may be Crown copyright (s.12); OGL-C allows commercial use with attribution; failure to attribute may breach license
Legal Basis: Copyright Act s.12; OGL-C; Reproduction of Federal Law Order
Mitigation Strategies: Always attribute Crown works; verify OGL-C compliance; check if Reproduction of Federal Law Order applies; obtain explicit permissions when uncertain

Description: Browse-wrap and click-wrap terms can be enforceable contracts restricting scraping, indexing, reproduction
Legal Basis: Century 21 v. Zoocasa (2011 BCSC 1196); Trader v. CarGurus (2017 ONSC 1841)
Mitigation Strategies: Review TOS before scraping; obtain licenses; respect robots.txt and technical restrictions; document compliance efforts

Description: PIPEDA prohibits collection/use/disclosure of personal information in commercial activities without consent; applies even to public court records
Mitigation Strategies: Redact personal information; avoid SEO-optimized republication of decisions with personal data; implement removal procedures; respect privacy principles

Description: Statutory damages: $500-$20,000/work (commercial); TPM circumvention prohibited; no actual harm proof required
Legal Basis: Copyright Act s.38.1 (statutory damages); ss.41.1-41.21 (TPM); Nintendo v. King (2017)
Mitigation Strategies: Never circumvent TPMs; respect paywalls and access controls; document licensing; consider statutory damages exposure in risk assessment

Description: Standard-form online contracts generally enforceable if adequate notice provided; unconscionability defense available in extreme cases
Legal Basis: Century 21 v. Zoocasa; Douez v. Facebook (2017 SCC 33); Uber v. Heller (2020 SCC 16)
Mitigation Strategies: Ensure TOS are clearly displayed and brought to users' attention; avoid unconscionable terms; consider bargaining power inequality

Description: Fair dealing defense narrow in Canada (research, private study, criticism, review, news reporting); commercial scraping unlikely to qualify
Legal Basis: Copyright Act s.29; Trader v. CarGurus (fair dealing rejected)
Mitigation Strategies: Do not rely on fair dealing for commercial scraping; obtain explicit licenses; document non-commercial research purposes if applicable

Description: Works prepared/published by/under Crown control vest copyright in Crown; includes survey plans, registry data
Legal Basis: Copyright Act s.12; Keatley v. Teranet (2019 SCC 43)
Mitigation Strategies: Verify whether data is Crown copyright; check for applicable open licenses (OGL-C); use Reproduction of Federal Law Order for federal legal materials

Description: May be unenforceable if unconscionable or contrary to public policy; inequality of bargaining power relevant
Legal Basis: Douez v. Facebook (2017 SCC 33); Uber v. Heller (2020 SCC 16); Dell v. Union des consommateurs (2007 SCC 34)
Mitigation Strategies: Evaluate enforceability based on bargaining power, notice, fairness; consider public policy issues; seek legal advice on consumer/adhesion contracts

Description: Emerging area; publishers alleging copyright infringement, TPM circumvention, breach of TOS for AI training
Legal Basis: Canadian Publishers v. OpenAI (2024, pending); CanLII v. Caseway AI (2024, pending)
Mitigation Strategies: Obtain explicit licenses for training data; respect robots.txt; do not circumvent TPMs; monitor ongoing litigation; implement compliance procedures

Description: Canadian courts may assert jurisdiction over foreign defendants with real and substantial connection to Canada
Legal Basis: A.T. v. Globe24h.com (2017 FC 114); Google v. Equustek (2017 SCC 34)
Mitigation Strategies: Assume Canadian law applies if serving Canadian users or scraping Canadian content; comply with Canadian copyright/privacy laws; consider global implications

Description: Platforms facilitating infringement may be liable; courts can order intermediaries (e.g., Google) to take action
Legal Basis: Google v. Equustek (2017 SCC 34 - worldwide de-indexing order)
Mitigation Strategies: Implement DMCA-style notice-and-takedown procedures; respond to court orders; maintain records of compliance

Description: Displaying content from another website (framing) constitutes 'making available' = copyright infringement
Mitigation Strategies: Do not frame third-party content without license; embed only with permission; use proper API access with authorization
